trans-unit.source: Deploy an Azure App Service API App
trans-unit.target: Deploy an Azure App Service API App

trans-unit.source: Learn how to deploy an API App project to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to deploy an API App project to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you're actively developing your own API app using Visual Studio and need to test your API in the cloud, you can create a new API app in your Azure subscription and deploy your code using Visual Studio's convenient App Service deployment features.
trans-unit.target: If you're actively developing your own API app using Visual Studio and need to test your API in the cloud, you can create a new API app in your Azure subscription and deploy your code using Visual Studio's convenient App Service deployment features.

trans-unit.source: This is the second tutorial in a series of three:
trans-unit.target: This is the second tutorial in a series of three:

trans-unit.source: In <linkText>Create an API App</linkText><title></title> you created an API App project.
trans-unit.target: In <linkText>Create an API App</linkText><title></title> you created an API App project.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will deploy the API app to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will deploy the API app to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: In <linkText>Debug an API App</linkText><title></title>, you will use Visual Studio to remotely debug the code while it runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In <linkText>Debug an API App</linkText><title></title>, you will use Visual Studio to remotely debug the code while it runs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and click Publish....
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and click Publish....

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Project publish menu option</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Project publish menu option</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Profile tab and click Microsoft Azure API Apps (Preview).
trans-unit.target: Click the Profile tab and click Microsoft Azure API Apps (Preview).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish Web dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish Web dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click New to provision a new API App in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Click New to provision a new API App in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Existing API Services dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Existing API Services dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Create an API App dialog, enter the following:
trans-unit.target: In the Create an API App dialog, enter the following:

trans-unit.source: Under API App Name, enter a name for the app.
trans-unit.target: Under API App Name, enter a name for the app.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, select the one you want to use.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, select the one you want to use.

trans-unit.source: -Under App Service Plan, select from your existing App Service plans, or select Create new App Service plan and enter the name of a new plan.
trans-unit.target: -Under App Service Plan, select from your existing App Service plans, or select Create new App Service plan and enter the name of a new plan.

trans-unit.source: Under Resource Group, select from your existing resource groups, or select Create new resource group and enter a name.
trans-unit.target: Under Resource Group, select from your existing resource groups, or select Create new resource group and enter a name.

trans-unit.source: The name must be unique; consider using the app name as a prefix and appending some personal information such as your Microsoft ID (without the @ sign).
trans-unit.target: The name must be unique; consider using the app name as a prefix and appending some personal information such as your Microsoft ID (without the @ sign).

trans-unit.source: Under Access Level, select Available to Anyone.
trans-unit.target: Under Access Level, select Available to Anyone.

trans-unit.source: This option will make your API completely public, which is fine for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This option will make your API completely public, which is fine for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You can restrict access later through the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: You can restrict access later through the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Select a region.
trans-unit.target: Select a region.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Microsoft Azure Web App dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Microsoft Azure Web App dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click OK to create the API App in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to create the API App in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: The process can take a few minutes, so Visual Studio shows a dialog notifying you that the process has initiated.
trans-unit.target: The process can take a few minutes, so Visual Studio shows a dialog notifying you that the process has initiated.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Service Creation Started confirmation message</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Service Creation Started confirmation message</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The provisioning process creates the resource group and API App in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: The provisioning process creates the resource group and API App in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio shows the progress in the Azure App Service Activity window.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio shows the progress in the Azure App Service Activity window.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Status notification via the Azure App Service Activity window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Status notification via the Azure App Service Activity window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Once the API App is provisioned, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish to re-open the publish dialog.
trans-unit.target: Once the API App is provisioned, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish to re-open the publish dialog.

trans-unit.source: The publish profile created in the previous step should be pre-selected.
trans-unit.target: The publish profile created in the previous step should be pre-selected.

trans-unit.source: Click Publish to begin the deployment process.
trans-unit.target: Click Publish to begin the deployment process.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Deploying the API App</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Deploying the API App</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Azure App Service Activity window shows the deployment progress.
trans-unit.target: The Azure App Service Activity window shows the deployment progress.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Status notification of the Azure App Service Activity window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Status notification of the Azure App Service Activity window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will navigate to the portal to view the basic settings available for API Apps and make iterative changes to your API app.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will navigate to the portal to view the basic settings available for API Apps and make iterative changes to your API app.

trans-unit.source: With each deployment, the portal will reflect the changes you're making to your API app.
trans-unit.target: With each deployment, the portal will reflect the changes you're making to your API app.

trans-unit.source: In your browser, navigate to the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In your browser, navigate to the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click the Browse button on the sidebar and select API Apps.
trans-unit.target: Click the Browse button on the sidebar and select API Apps.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Browse options on Azure portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Browse options on Azure portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the API you created from the list of API apps in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Select the API you created from the list of API apps in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Apps list</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Apps list</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click API Definition.
trans-unit.target: Click API Definition.

trans-unit.source: The app's API Definition blade shows the list of API operations that you defined when you created the app.
trans-unit.target: The app's API Definition blade shows the list of API operations that you defined when you created the app.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now go back to the project in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Now go back to the project in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the ContactsController.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the ContactsController.cs file.

trans-unit.source: This code adds a Post method that can be used to post new Contact instances to the API.
trans-unit.target: This code adds a Post method that can be used to post new Contact instances to the API.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Adding the Post method to the controller</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Adding the Post method to the controller</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Project Publish context menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Project Publish context menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the Debug configuration from Configuration drop-down and click Publish to redeploy the API app.
trans-unit.target: Select the Debug configuration from Configuration drop-down and click Publish to redeploy the API app.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish Web settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish Web settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Preview tab of the Publish Web wizard, click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In the Preview tab of the Publish Web wizard, click Publish.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish Web dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish Web dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Once the publish process has completed, go back to the portal, and close and reopen the API Definition blade.
trans-unit.target: Once the publish process has completed, go back to the portal, and close and reopen the API Definition blade.

trans-unit.source: You will see the new API endpoint you just created and deployed directly into your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You will see the new API endpoint you just created and deployed directly into your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Definition</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You've seen how the direct deployment capabilities in Visual Studio make it easy to iterate and deploy rapidly and test that your API works correctly.
trans-unit.target: You've seen how the direct deployment capabilities in Visual Studio make it easy to iterate and deploy rapidly and test that your API works correctly.

trans-unit.source: In the <linkText>next tutorial</linkText><title></title>, you'll see how to debug your API app while it runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In the <linkText>next tutorial</linkText><title></title>, you'll see how to debug your API app while it runs in Azure.
